title: World's most asked questions: how can I get rid of the hiccups?

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of the diaphragm in the human body?
What is a hiccup, and what causes it?

options.label: A
options.text: A hiccup is a voluntary contraction of the diaphragm caused by eating too quickly.

options.label: B
options.text: A hiccup is an involuntary spasm of the diaphragm that causes it to contract suddenly.

options.label: C
options.text: A hiccup is a result of a malfunctioning vagus nerve.

options.label: D
options.text: A hiccup is a side effect of drinking too much water.

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of the vagus nerve in relation to hiccups?

options.label: A
options.text: The vagus nerve causes hiccups by stimulating the diaphragm.

options.label: B
options.text: The vagus nerve helps to regulate breathing and can be stimulated to stop hiccups.

options.label: C
options.text: The vagus nerve has no relation to hiccups.

options.label: D
options.text: The vagus nerve is responsible for regulating heartbeat only.

multiple-choice.question: How does swallowing a teaspoon of sugar help to get rid of hiccups?

options.label: A
options.text: The sugar provides energy for the diaphragm to function properly.

options.label: B
options.text: The act of gulping down dry granules stimulates the vagus nerve, distracting it from the diaphragm.

options.label: C
options.text: The sugar helps to regulate CO2 levels in the bloodstream.

options.label: D
options.text: The sugar has no effect on hiccups.

multiple-choice.question: What is the most common approach to getting rid of hiccups?

options.label: B
options.text: Increasing the level of carbon dioxide in the bloodstream

multiple-choice.question: How does holding one's breath help to get rid of hiccups?

options.label: B
options.text: It increases the level of oxygen in the bloodstream.

options.label: C
options.text: It increases the level of carbon dioxide in the bloodstream, signaling the diaphragm to function properly.

options.label: D
options.text: It has no effect on hiccups.

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of the diaphragm contracting suddenly during a hiccup?

options.label: A
options.text: The vocal folds open, allowing air to enter the lungs.

options.label: B
options.text: The vocal folds clamp shut, causing the "hic" sound.

options.label: C
options.text: The diaphragm relaxes, stopping the hiccup.

multiple-choice.question: According to the SciShow Survey, what is the most preferred method for relieving hiccups?
What is the purpose of the World's Most Asked Questions series?

options.label: A
options.text: To answer questions about science and nature.

options.label: B
options.text: To provide remedies for common ailments.

options.label: C
options.text: To explore the human body and its functions.

options.label: D
options.text: To answer the most popular questions searched for on the internet.

multiple-choice.question: How can one submit a question to be answered in a future video?

options.label: B
options.text: By using the hashtag #WMAQ on social media.

options.label: C
options.text: By filling out the SciShow Survey.

title: How do you know if you have a virus? - Cella Wright

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary purpose of PCR (Polymerase Chain Reaction) testing in the context of viral infections?

options.label: A
options.text: To detect the presence of antibodies in the body

options.label: B
options.text: To diagnose someone who is currently infected with a virus

options.label: C
options.text: To identify the genetic material of a virus in the environment

options.label: D
options.text: To develop a vaccine against a virus

multiple-choice.question: What is the main difference between PCR testing and immunoassays in the context of viral infections?

options.label: A
options.text: PCR testing detects the presence of antibodies, while immunoassays detect the presence of the virus

options.label: B
options.text: PCR testing detects the presence of the virus, while immunoassays detect the presence of antibodies

options.label: C
options.text: PCR testing is used for diagnosing current infections, while immunoassays are used for diagnosing past infections

options.label: D
options.text: PCR testing is used for diagnosing past infections, while immunoassays are used for diagnosing current infections

multiple-choice.question: What is the first step in developing a PCR test for a never-before-seen virus?

options.label: A
options.text: Collecting a sample from an infected individual

options.label: B
options.text: Sequencing the genetic material of the virus

options.label: C
options.text: Identifying regions of the virus that are unique to that specific virus

options.label: D
options.text: Running the PCR test on a sample

multiple-choice.question: What type of genetic material is targeted by PCR testing?
What is the purpose of reverse transcription in PCR testing?

options.label: A
options.text: To amplify the genetic material of the virus

options.label: C
options.text: To detect the presence of antibodies

options.label: D
options.text: To identify the genetic material of the virus

multiple-choice.question: What is the function of primers in PCR testing?

options.label: A
options.text: To amplify the genetic material of the virus

options.label: B
options.text: To detect the presence of antibodies

options.label: C
options.text: To identify the unique regions of the virus

multiple-choice.question: What type of antibodies are typically detected by immunoassays to indicate a recent infection?

options.label: A
options.text: As a treatment for people who are currently fighting the virus

options.label: B
options.text: As a vaccine against the virus

options.label: C
options.text: As a diagnostic tool for detecting the presence of the virus

options.label: D
options.text: As a research tool for studying the virus

multiple-choice.question: What is the advantage of digital PCR over traditional PCR?

options.label: A
options.text: It is faster and more efficient

options.label: B
options.text: It is more accurate and can quantify individual pieces of target DNA

options.label: C
options.text: It is less expensive and more widely available

options.label: D
options.text: It is more sensitive and can detect smaller amounts of genetic material

multiple-choice.question: Why are immunoassays important in the context of viral infections?

options.label: C
options.text: They can detect the presence of antibodies

options.label: D
options.text: They can detect the presence of the virus

title: Why do bats carry so many diseases? (like coronavirus)

multiple-choice.question: What is a common factor among the viruses Nipah, Hendra, Ebola, Marburg, and SARS?

options.label: B
options.text: They are all carried by bats

options.label: C
options.text: They all have a high mortality rate

multiple-choice.question: (Factual) What is a likely reason for the recent rise in outbreaks of diseases carried by bats?

options.label: B
options.text: Humans and animals are encroaching on bats' territory

options.label: C
options.text: Bats are evolving to become more disease-prone

multiple-choice.question: (Conceptual) Why do bats appear to carry more human-killing diseases than other animals?

options.label: A
options.text: Bats have a weak immune system

options.label: B
options.text: Bats are more social and live in close quarters, allowing viruses to spread easily

options.label: C
options.text: Bats have a unique physiology that makes them more susceptible to disease

options.label: D
options.text: Bats are more likely to come into contact with humans

multiple-choice.question: (Factual) What is a unique adaptation that allows bats to survive deadly viruses?

options.label: C
options.text: Their ability to produce reactive waste products

options.label: D
options.text: Their DNA damage repair kits and specialized cells

multiple-choice.question: (Conceptual) How do viruses that infect bats become more resilient to human defenses?

options.label: A
options.text: By evolving to tolerate the heat generated by bats during flight

options.label: D
options.text: By mutating into more virulent forms

multiple-choice.question: (Application) What can humans learn from bats in terms of disease prevention?

options.label: A
options.text: How to develop more effective vaccines

options.label: B
options.text: How to improve our immune system

options.label: C
options.text: How to prevent the spread of diseases through better hygiene

options.label: D
options.text: How to be more resilient to cancer

multiple-choice.question: (Analytical) What is the main argument made by the author regarding the relationship between bats and human disease?

options.label: A
options.text: Bats are the primary carriers of human disease and should be eradicated

options.label: B
options.text: Bats are not the primary carriers of human disease, and humans should focus on controlling the spread of diseases carried by other animals

options.label: C
options.text: Bats are a necessary part of the ecosystem, and their role in disease transmission is overstated

options.label: D
options.text: Bats are a major threat to human health, and their populations should be controlled

multiple-choice.question: (Factual) What is the mortality rate of hemorrhagic fevers like Ebola?
(Conceptual) Why are bats important to the ecosystem?

options.label: A
options.text: They are a food source for other animals

options.label: B
options.text: They pollinate plants and control insect populations

options.label: C
options.text: They are a source of disease transmission

options.label: D
options.text: They are a nuisance to humans

multiple-choice.question: (Application) What is a suggested solution to reducing the spread of diseases carried by bats?

options.label: C
options.text: Leaving bats alone and focusing on controlling the spread of diseases carried by other animals

options.label: D
options.text: Reducing human encroachment on bat habitats

options.label: A
options.text: To remove the last letter of the word.

options.label: B
options.text: To add "ing" to the end of the word.

options.label: C
options.text: To add "ed" to the end of the word.

options.label: D
options.text: To reverse the order of the word.

options.text: Because only verbs can be used to travel through time.

title: What is a coronavirus? - Elizabeth Cox

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the cave where scientists finally found the source of the deadly new virus that caused the SARS epidemic in 2003?

options.label: A
options.text: They have a long, helical shape

options.label: B
options.text: They have little protein spikes that resemble a crown

multiple-choice.question: How many known human coronaviruses are there, and what diseases do they cause?

options.label: A
options.text: 5, causing SARS, MERS, COVID-19, and two types of colds

options.label: B
options.text: 7, causing SARS, MERS, COVID-19, and four types of colds

options.label: C
options.text: 10, causing SARS, MERS, COVID-19, and seven types of colds

options.label: D
options.text: 12, causing SARS, MERS, COVID-19, and nine types of colds

multiple-choice.question: How do coronaviruses typically transmit from person to person?

options.label: B
options.text: Through direct contact with an infected person's skin

options.label: C
options.text: Through droplets containing the virus that are released when an infected person coughs

multiple-choice.question: What is a key factor that determines the survival and transmission of coronaviruses?
What is the primary mechanism by which coronaviruses replicate their genes?

options.label: A
options.text: By hijacking the host cell's DNA replication machinery

options.label: B
options.text: By using their own DNA replication machinery

options.label: C
options.text: By hijacking the host cell's machinery to replicate their own RNA

options.label: D
options.text: By using their own RNA replication machinery

multiple-choice.question: What is a characteristic of RNA viruses, including coronaviruses, that makes them more prone to mutations?

options.label: A
options.text: They have a proofreading mechanism to correct replication errors

options.label: B
options.text: They have a large number of genes, making them more stable

options.label: C
options.text: They lack a proofreading mechanism, making them more prone to errors

options.label: D
options.text: They have a slow mutation rate, making them more stable

multiple-choice.question: What is a unique feature of coronaviruses that helps to counteract the risk of harmful mutations?

options.label: A
options.text: They have a small number of genes, making them less prone to errors

options.label: B
options.text: They have an enzyme that checks for replication errors and corrects mistakes

options.label: C
options.text: They have a high mutation rate, allowing them to adapt quickly

options.label: D
options.text: They have a proofreading mechanism, making them more stable

multiple-choice.question: Why do we need a new flu vaccine every year?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the influenza virus has a slow mutation rate

options.label: B
options.text: Because the influenza virus mutates quickly, creating new strains

options.label: C
options.text: Because the influenza virus is an RNA virus

options.label: D
options.text: Because the influenza virus is a DNA virus

multiple-choice.question: What is a potential benefit of the slow mutation rate of coronaviruses?

options.label: A
options.text: It makes them more contagious and harder to treat

options.label: B
options.text: It makes them less recognizable to our immune systems

options.label: C
options.text: It makes our immune systems, drugs, and vaccines less effective

options.label: D
options.text: It allows our immune systems, drugs, and vaccines to recognize them for longer, providing better protection

options.text: By using historical and factual information

options.label: D
options.text: By using scientific and technical terms

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: B

title: Fabulous food chains

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary source of energy in a food chain?
What is a food chain, according to the transcript?

options.label: B
options.text: A model that shows how energy flows between living things

multiple-choice.question: What is an ecosystem, according to the transcript?

options.label: C
options.text: A self-contained collection of different things that all work together as a whole

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the energy from the Sun in a food chain?

options.label: A
options.text: It is lost in the environment

options.label: C
options.text: It is transferred from plants to animals

multiple-choice.question: Why are humans considered to be at the top of the food chain?

options.label: A
options.text: Because we are the largest animals

options.label: B
options.text: Because we are the strongest animals

options.label: C
options.text: Because we eat a wide variety of foods and have few natural predators

options.label: D
options.text: Because we are the fastest animals

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of plants in a food chain?

options.label: B
options.text: To produce energy from the Sun

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the energy from a plant when an animal eats it?

options.label: B
options.text: The energy is stored in the plant

options.label: C
options.text: The energy is transferred to the animal

options.label: D
options.text: The energy is created by the animal

multiple-choice.question: What is a habitat, according to the transcript?

options.label: C
options.text: The natural environment in which an organism lives

multiple-choice.question: Why are most living things in more than one food chain?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they only eat one type of food

options.label: B
options.text: Because they have a fixed diet

options.label: C
options.text: Because they eat different foods at different times

options.label: D
options.text: Because they are only in one ecosystem

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of creating a diagram of a food chain?

options.label: A
options.text: To show the different types of plants in an ecosystem

options.label: B
options.text: To show the different types of animals in an ecosystem

options.label: C
options.text: To show how energy flows between living things in an ecosystem

options.label: D
options.text: To show the water cycle in an ecosystem

title: Why don't haircuts hurt?

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary reason why cutting hair does not hurt?

options.label: A
options.text: Hair is made of a special type of tissue that cannot feel pain.

options.label: B
options.text: Hair does not have nerves inside it.

options.label: C
options.text: Hair is too thin to feel pain.

options.label: D
options.text: Hair grows too slowly to feel pain.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main function of nerves in the human body?

options.label: B
options.text: To carry messages between different parts of the body.

options.label: C
options.text: To produce hormones and regulate body functions.

options.label: D
options.text: To protect the body from external damage.

multiple-choice.question: Which of the following senses is closely related to the sense of touch?
What is the primary role of nerves in the sense of touch?

options.label: C
options.text: To detect chemicals in the air.

options.label: D
options.text: To detect sensations such as pressure, temperature, and texture.

multiple-choice.question: Why can we feel sensations on our skin but not on our hair?

options.label: A
options.text: Because our skin is thicker than our hair.

options.label: B
options.text: Because our skin has nerves, but our hair does not.

options.label: C
options.text: Because our skin is more sensitive than our hair.

options.label: D
options.text: Because our hair is too thin to feel sensations.

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the messages sent by nerves when they reach the brain?

options.label: B
options.text: They are stored in memory for later use.

options.label: D
options.text: They are sent back to the original source.

multiple-choice.question: Which part of the body plays a crucial role in processing sensory information from nerves?
Why does it not hurt to cut fingernails and toenails?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they are made of a hard, keratin-based material.

options.label: B
options.text: Because they do not have nerves inside them.

options.label: C
options.text: Because they are too small to feel pain.

options.label: D
options.text: Because they grow too slowly to feel pain.

multiple-choice.question: What would happen if you were to pull on your hair while cutting it?

options.label: B
options.text: You would feel a slight tingling sensation.

options.label: C
options.text: You would feel pain because the pulling action stimulates nerves in the skin.

options.label: D
options.text: You would feel no sensation at all.

multiple-choice.question: How do nerves help us sense the world around us?

options.label: C
options.text: By detecting sensations such as pressure, temperature, and texture.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main idea of the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: To explain the structure and function of nerves in the human body.

options.label: B
options.text: To describe the process of cutting hair and why it does not hurt.

options.label: C
options.text: To explore the relationship between nerves and the sense of touch.

options.label: D
options.text: To discuss the importance of nerves in our daily lives.

title: Why is my leg asleep?

multiple-choice.question: What is the common term for the tingling sensation you feel when your arm or leg "wakes up" after being numb?
What happens to the blood vessels when you sit in one position or lean on your arm or leg for a while?

options.label: A
options.text: They expand and allow more blood to flow

options.label: B
options.text: They stay the same size and allow the same amount of blood to flow

options.label: C
options.text: They constrict and allow less blood to flow

options.label: D
options.text: They disappear and stop blood from flowing

multiple-choice.question: Why do nerves stop working well when they don't receive enough blood?

options.label: C
options.text: Because they need blood to function properly

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the nerves when they "wake up" after being numb?

options.label: B
options.text: They take a few hours to start working normally

options.label: C
options.text: They get a little confused and send wrong signals to the brain

options.label: D
options.text: They disappear and new nerves grow

multiple-choice.question: What is the function of nerves in the body?

options.label: A
options.text: To pump blood throughout the body

options.label: C
options.text: To send signals to the brain about sensations and feelings

multiple-choice.question: How can you prevent getting pins and needles?

options.label: A
options.text: By sitting in one position for a long time

options.label: B
options.text: By leaning on your arm or leg for a while

options.label: C
options.text: By making sure you don't sit or lean in one position for too long

options.label: D
options.text: By shaking your arms and legs constantly

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the prickling sensation after a minute or two?

options.label: D
options.text: It spreads to other parts of the body

multiple-choice.question: Why do people say that an arm or leg "fell asleep" when it becomes numb?

options.label: C
options.text: Because it is not receiving enough blood

options.label: D
options.text: Because it feels like it is sleeping and not responding to sensations

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of blood in the body?

options.label: A
options.text: To send signals to the brain

options.label: C
options.text: To provide energy to different parts of the body

multiple-choice.question: What can you do to help the blood flow again when you get pins and needles?

options.label: B
options.text: Shake the affected arm or leg

options.label: C
options.text: Apply heat or cold to the affected area

options.label: D
options.text: Take medication to relieve the sensation

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the machine that makes more than one of every word?

options.text: To indicate more than one of something

title: Closed and open syllables | Learn to read

multiple-choice.question: What is the rule for the vowel sound in an open syllable?

options.label: A
options.text: The vowel makes a short sound.

options.label: B
options.text: The vowel says its letter name.

options.label: D
options.text: The vowel makes a long sound, but not its letter name.

multiple-choice.question: Which of the following words is an example of an open syllable?

options.label: C
options.text: me (when me is pronounced with a short 'e')

options.label: D
options.text: no (when no is pronounced with a short 'o')

multiple-choice.question: What is the rule for the vowel sound in a closed syllable?

options.label: A
options.text: The vowel says its letter name.

options.label: B
options.text: The vowel makes a short sound.

options.label: D
options.text: The vowel makes a long sound.

multiple-choice.question: Which of the following words is an example of a closed syllable?

options.label: C
options.text: me (when me is pronounced with a long 'e')

options.label: D
options.text: no (when no is pronounced with a long 'o')

multiple-choice.question: Analyze the word "no" when pronounced with a long 'o'. What type of syllable is it?
Apply the rule for open and closed syllables to a new situation. What type of syllable is the word "go" when pronounced with a long 'o'?
Which of the following words follows the rule for a closed syllable?

options.label: C
options.text: me (when me is pronounced with a long 'e')

options.label: D
options.text: no (when no is pronounced with a long 'o')

multiple-choice.question: What is the main difference between an open and a closed syllable?

options.label: A
options.text: The vowel sound is the same in both.

options.label: B
options.text: The vowel sound is shorter in an open syllable.

options.label: C
options.text: The vowel sound is longer in a closed syllable.

options.label: D
options.text: The vowel sound is shorter in a closed syllable and longer in an open syllable.

multiple-choice.question: Identify the correct statement about open and closed syllables.

options.label: A
options.text: In an open syllable, the vowel makes a short sound, and in a closed syllable, the vowel says its letter name.

options.label: B
options.text: In an open syllable, the vowel says its letter name, and in a closed syllable, the vowel makes a short sound.

options.label: C
options.text: In both open and closed syllables, the vowel makes a short sound.

options.label: D
options.text: In both open and closed syllables, the vowel says its letter name.

multiple-choice.question: Apply the rule for open and closed syllables to a new situation. What type of syllable is the word "my" when pronounced with a long 'y' (sometimes considered a vowel)?

title: The L-iminator! | The double L spelling rule

multiple-choice.question: What is a compound word in the English language?

options.label: A
options.text: A word that is broken down into two separate words

options.label: B
options.text: A new word formed by joining two words together

options.label: C
options.text: A word that is used in two different contexts

options.label: D
options.text: A word that has two opposite meanings

multiple-choice.question: What happens to one of the L's when two words join together to form a compound word, and both words end in L?

options.label: B
options.text: One of the L's is eliminated

options.label: C
options.text: The L's are replaced with another letter

options.label: D
options.text: The L's are moved to a different position in the word

multiple-choice.question: What is the correct spelling of the compound word formed by joining "all" and "though"?
What is the purpose of eliminating one of the L's in a compound word?

options.label: B
options.text: To change the meaning of the word

options.label: C
options.text: To make the word easier to pronounce

options.label: D
options.text: To follow the standard spelling convention

multiple-choice.question: Can you think of a situation where two words join together to form a new word, but no letters are eliminated?

options.label: A
options.text: Yes, when the words are short

options.label: B
options.text: Yes, when the words are long

options.label: D
options.text: Yes, when the words have different spellings

multiple-choice.question: What is the correct spelling of the compound word formed by joining "un" and "til"?
What happens to the meaning of the individual words when they join together to form a compound word?
Can you think of a situation where a compound word is formed by joining three words together?

options.label: C
options.text: Yes, but only in certain languages

options.label: D
options.text: Yes, but only in certain contexts

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of using compound words in the English language?

options.label: C
options.text: To create new words with unique meanings

multiple-choice.question: What is the effect of eliminating one of the L's in a compound word on the pronunciation of the word?

title: Human, capital & natural resources for kids | Types of resources

multiple-choice.question: What is a resource?

options.label: A
options.text: Something that people make for fun

options.label: B
options.text: Something that people use to meet their needs

options.label: C
options.text: Something that people find in space

options.label: D
options.text: Something that people use to play games

multiple-choice.question: What are the three main types of resources?
What is an example of a human resource?

options.label: B
options.text: A doctor who helps people feel better

multiple-choice.question: What is a service?

options.label: A
options.text: Something that someone makes for you

options.label: B
options.text: Something that someone does for you

options.label: C
options.text: Something that someone sells to you

options.label: D
options.text: Something that someone buys from you

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of a capital resource?
What are natural resources?

options.label: A
options.text: Things that are made by people

options.label: B
options.text: Things that are found on earth and can be used by people

options.label: C
options.text: Things that are found in space and can be used by people

options.label: D
options.text: Things that are made by machines

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of a natural resource?

options.label: A
options.text: They use them to make food for people to eat

options.label: B
options.text: They use them to provide medical care to people

options.label: C
options.text: They use them to build houses for people

options.label: D
options.text: They use them to teach students in school

multiple-choice.question: Why are human resources important?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they provide services and make goods for people

options.label: B
options.text: Because they make capital resources for people

options.label: C
options.text: Because they find natural resources for people

options.label: D
options.text: Because they build houses for people

multiple-choice.question: What is the main difference between natural resources and capital resources?

options.label: A
options.text: Natural resources are made by people, while capital resources are found on earth

options.label: B
options.text: Natural resources are found on earth, while capital resources are made by people

options.label: C
options.text: Natural resources are used to make goods, while capital resources are used to provide services

options.label: D
